across.text: Muse, when given info, probing twitch causing malformation
across.explanation: TERATOGENIC(i.e. “causing malformation” – over to Chambers: “producing monsters; causing abnormal growth (in a fetus)”). Solution is ERATO (one of the Greek “muses”) and GEN (i.e. “info”) both placed in or “probing” TIC (i.e. “twitch”), like so: T(ERATO-GEN)IC. This clue brought to mind the title of an extreme horror novella by Edward Lee and Wrath James White calledThe Teratologist. I’ll leave it up to the sick puppies among you to look it up. It ain’tBook At Bedtimematerial, that’s for sure.

across.text: Set up area to have meal outside
across.explanation: LAUNCH(i.e. “set up”). Solution is A (a recognised abbreviation of “area”) placed in or “having…outside” LUNCH (i.e. “meal”), like so: L(A)UNCH.

across.text: A joke about being doddery
across.explanation: GAGA(i.e. “doddery”). Solution is A and GAG (i.e. “joke”) all reversed (indicated by “about”), like so: GAG-A.

across.text: Actor in America: act’s ending with popular love verse
across.explanation: PeterUSTINOV(i.e. “actor”). Solution is US (i.e. “America”) followed by T (i.e. “act’s ending”, i.e. the last letter of “act”), then IN (i.e. “popular”), then O (i.e. “love”, a zero score in tennis) and V (a recognised abbreviation of “verse”).

across.text: Overact as radio geek with modern technology increased?
across.explanation: HAM IT UP(i.e. “overact”). Solution is HAM (i.e. “radio geek”) followed by IT (i.e. “modern technology”) and UP (i.e. “increased”).

across.text: Number joining the woman outside work that no-one would fancy?
across.explanation: NO-HOPER(i.e. “that no-one would fancy”). Solution is NO (short for “number”) followed by HER (i.e. “the woman”) once wrapped around or placed “outside” of OP (i.e. “work”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “opus”), like so: NO-H(OP)ER.

across.text: Sculptor as one to fashion government offices
across.explanation: PROCONSULATES(i.e. Roman “government offices”, apparently). “To fashion” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of SCULPTOR AS ONE.

across.text: Former English politician (one in a hundred) getting let-off
across.explanation: EXEMPTION(i.e. “let-off”). Solution is EX (i.e. “former”) followed by E (a recognised abbreviation of “English”), then MP (i.e. “politician”, specifically a Member of Parliament), then I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) once placed “in” TON (i.e. “a hundred”), like so: EX-E-MP-T(I)ON.

across.text: Draw sketches maybe moving around church
across.explanation: TRACE(i.e. to “draw”). Solution is ART (i.e. “sketches maybe”) reversed (indicated by “moving around”) and followed by CE (i.e. “church”, specifically the Church of England), like so: TRA-CE.

across.text: Film about old school is exposing hater of marriage
across.explanation: MISOGAMIST(i.e. “hater of marriage”). Solution is MIST (i.e. a “film” of moisture) wrapped “about” O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”), GAM (i.e. a “school” or pod of whales) and IS, like so: MIS(O-GAM-IS)T.

across.text: What may sound like iron temperament
across.explanation: METTLE(i.e. “temperament”). “What may sound like” indicates homophone. Solution is a homophone of METAL (i.e. “iron”).

across.text: What’s falsely portrayed about Queen brings conflict
across.explanation: FRICTION(i.e. “conflict”). Solution is FICTION (i.e. “what’s falsely portrayed”) wrapped “about” R (i.e. “queen”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of the LatinRegina), like so: F(R)ICTION.

across.text: Daughter is going to gig with blokes, event ultimately producing upset
across.explanation: DISCONCERTMENT(i.e. “upset”). Solution is D (a recognised abbreviation of “daughter”) followed by IS, then CONCERT (i.e. “gig”), then MEN (i.e. “blokes”) and T (i.e. “event ultimately”, i.e. the last letter of “event”).

across.text: Woman in the course of time to become mean?
across.explanation: AVERAGE(i.e. mathematical “mean”). Solution is VERA (i.e. “woman’s” name) placed “in” AGE (i.e. “the course of time”), like so: A(VERA)GE.

across.text: Not favouring Eastern jewellery for presents
across.explanation: OFFERINGS(i.e. “presents”). Solution is OFF (i.e. “not favouring”) followed by E (a recognised abbreviation of “Eastern”), then RINGS (i.e. “jewellery”).

across.text: Reptile with label turning yellow
across.explanation: GATOR(i.e. “reptile”). Solution is TAG (i.e. “label”) reversed (indicated by “turning”) and followed by OR (i.e. “yellow” or gold in heraldry), like so: GAT-OR.

across.text: Drunk this evening? That’s not on!
across.explanation: TIGHT(i.e. “drunk”). Solution is TONIGHT (i.e. “this evening”) with the ON removed (indicated by “that’s not on”).

across.text: They have offensive weapons? They must be charged
across.explanation: BATTERIES. Solution satisfies “they have offensive weapons” and “they must be charged”.

across.text: Grumble with the old woman down below
across.explanation: MAUNDER(i.e. “grumble”). Solution is MA (i.e. “old woman”, both informal terms for mother) followed by UNDER (i.e. “down below”).

across.text: Computer feature, from being uninitialised, expanded?
across.explanation: READ-ONLY MEMORY(i.e. “computer feature”). Solution is FROM with the first letter removed (indicated by “uninitialised”). The remainder, ROM, is a recognised abbreviation of the solution.

across.text: Have a bit of time with girls – that’s sweet
across.explanation: MOLASSES(i.e. “that’s sweet”). Solution is MO (i.e. “a bit of time”, short for a moment) followed by LASSES (i.e. “girls”).

across.text: Tears apart the character finally appearing as substitute
across.explanation: ERSATZ(i.e. “substitute”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “apart”) of TEARS followed by Z (i.e. “the character finally”, i.e. the last letter of the alphabet), like so: ERSAT-Z.

across.text: A series of points suggesting one should sign up?
across.explanation: DOTTED LINE. Solution satisfies the clue as a whole. Not much to add to that, really.

across.text: Time to go to India to find enchantress
across.explanation: HOURI(i.e. “enchantress” – no, me neither). Solution is HOUR (i.e. “time”) followed by I (“India” in the phonetic alphabet).

across.text: Instrument in a workplace knocked over by travelling dog
across.explanation: BALALAIKA(i.e. “instrument”). Solution is A and LAB (i.e. “workplace”, short for laboratory) all reversed (indicated by “knocked over”) and followed by LAIKA (i.e. “travelling dog” – she was one of the first animals sent into space), like so: (BAL-A)-LAIKA.

across.text: Prisoners OK for being disciplined, not beyond being controlled
across.explanation: CONSTRAINABLE(i.e. “not beyond being controlled”). When written as CONS TRAINABLE the solution also satisfies “prisoners OK for being disciplined”.

across.text: Engineers facing gales maybe – procedures to start again?
across.explanation: REWINDS(i.e. “procedures to start again”). Solution is RE (i.e. “engineers”, specifically the Royal Engineers of the British Army) followed by WINDS (i.e. “gales maybe”).

across.text: Statement of personal ambition to pen lines revealing malice
across.explanation: ILL WILL(i.e. “malice”). Solution is I WILL (i.e. “statement of personal ambition”) wrapped around or “penning” L and L (both recognised abbreviations of “line”), like so: I-(LL)-WILL.

across.text: Country peasants ultimately embraced by public schoolboy without end
across.explanation: ESTONIA(i.e. “country”). Solution is S (i.e. “peasants ultimately”, i.e. the last letter of “peasants”) placed in or “embraced by” ETONIAN (i.e. “public schoolboy”) once the last letter has been removed (indicated by “without end”), like so: E(S)TONIA.

across.text: Plant seen in old vessel, round to the left
across.explanation: OKRA(i.e. “plant”). Solution is O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”) followed by ARK (i.e. “vessel”) once reversed (indicated by “to the left” – this being an across clue), like so: O-KRA.

across.text: What’s expected – disciple becoming minister
across.explanation: PARSON(i.e. “minister”). Solution is PAR (i.e. “what’s expected”) followed by SON (i.e. “disciple”).

across.text: Log – wood that can be eaten!
across.explanation: MINUTE STEAK(i.e. “that can be eaten”). Solution is MINUTES (i.e. “log” of a meeting) followed by TEAK (i.e. “wood”).

down.text: Elephantine yell of loose woman losing head
down.explanation: TRUMPET(i.e. “elephantine yell”). Solution is STRUMPET (i.e. “loose woman”) with the first letter removed (indicated by “losing head”).

down.text: New realisation brings excuse
down.explanation: RATIONALISE(i.e. to “excuse”). “New” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of REALISATION.

down.text: Dance with zest and love
down.explanation: TANGO(i.e. “dance”). Solution is TANG (i.e. “zest”) followed by O (i.e. “love”, covered earlier).

down.text: Call a person to allocate belfry duty?
down.explanation: GIVE SOMEONE A BELL. Solution satisfies “call a person” and, playfully, “allocate belfry duty”.

down.text: Sort of philosopher’s province, greeting cant
down.explanation: NIHILIST(i.e. “sort of philosopher”). Solution is NI (i.e. “province”, specifically Northern Ireland) followed by HI (i.e. “greeting”) and CANT (i.e. incline or “list”)

down.text: Violent ma got fierce and suffered badly
down.explanation: CAME TO GRIEF(i.e. “suffered badly”). “Violent” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of MA GOT FIERCE.

down.text: Car plant
down.explanation: LOTUS. Solution satisfies “car” brand and “plant”. Simple but elegant.

down.text: Disagreeable incident when a Parisian worker carrying requests meets head
down.explanation: UNPLEASANTNESS(i.e. “disagreeable incident”). Solution is UN (i.e. “a Parisian”, i.e. the French for “a”) and ANT (i.e. “worker”) wrapped around or “carrying” PLEAS (i.e. “requests”). This is all then followed by NESS (i.e. “head”, both geographic features), like so: (UN-(PLEAS)-ANT)-NESS.

down.text: Report of triumph over one of two in autumn game
down.explanation: CONKER(i.e. “one of two in autumn game”). “Report of” indicates homophone. Solution is a homophone of CONQUER (i.e. “triumph”).

down.text: A bit of the argument intended to be heard in scheduled meeting?
down.explanation: APPOINTMENT(i.e. “scheduled meeting”). Solution is A followed by P (i.e. “bit” or coin, in this case short for a penny), then POINT (i.e. “argument”) and a homophone (indicated by “to be heard”) of MEANT (i.e. “intended”), like so: A-P-POINT-MENT.

down.text: A right row or “do”
down.explanation: ARRANGE(i.e. “do”). Solution is A followed by R (a recognised abbreviation of “right”) and RANGE (i.e. “row”).

down.text: Sailors taking time to produce cargo?
down.explanation: SHIPMENT(i.e. “cargo”). Solution is SHIPMEN (i.e. “sailors”) followed by T (a recognised abbreviation of “time”).

down.text: Competitor, not entirely intelligent, ranting
down.explanation: ENTRANT(i.e. “competitor”). “Not entirely” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, like so: INTELLIG(ENT RANT)ING.

down.text: Scottish officer? A Scot with little hesitation
down.explanation: MACER(i.e. “Scottish officer” of the courts). Solution is MAC (i.e. “a Scot”) followed by ER (i.e. “little hesitation”).

down.text: Tell a person off in no uncertain terms, but don’t remove computer?
down.explanation: LET SOMEONE HAVE IT. Solution satisfies “tell a person off in no uncertain terms” and, playfully, “don’t remove computer” – IT being short for Information Technology.

down.text: Praise female – second
down.explanation: FLATTER(i.e. “praise”). Solution is F (a recognised abbreviation of “female”) followed by LATTER (i.e. the “second” of two things).

down.text: Fighters hurting, climbing at foot of hill
down.explanation: TOREROS(i.e. “fighters”, specifically bullfighters on foot). Solution is SORE (i.e. “hurting”) reversed (indicated by “climbing” – this being a down clue) and placed after or “at foot of” TOR (i.e. “hill”), like so: TOR-EROS.

down.text: People in the same school class maybe rose with importance unexpectedly
down.explanation: CONTEMPORARIES(i.e. “people in the same school class maybe”). “Unexpectedly” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of ROSE and IMPORTANCE.

down.text: Abandoning hotel, fiend has smashed dish
down.explanation: GOULASH(i.e. “dish”). Solution is GHOUL (i.e. “fiend”) with the H removed (indicated by “abandoning hotel” – H being “hotel” in the phonetic alphabet) and the remainder followed by an anagram (indicated by “smashed”) of HAS, like so: GOUL-ASH.

down.text: One whose work might result in a fiasco
down.explanation: GLASSBLOWER. Solution satisfies the clue as a whole – a variant meaning of “fiasco” is a flask or bottle.

down.text: Cornish tourist in ME upset police force
down.explanation: EMMET(i.e. “Cornish tourist”, or, more specifically, a Cornish term for a tourist. Made to fit, anyone?) Solution is ME reversed (indicated by “upset” – this being a down clue) and followed by MET (i.e. “police force”, specifically the London Metropolitan Police), like so: EM-MET.

down.text: Stir with dire men out to create political movement wanting land grab?
down.explanation: IRREDENTISM(i.e. “political movement wanting land grab”. Over to Chambers again: “the doctrine of ‘redeeming’ territory from another state, especially where there is some historical claim to the territory or when an ethnic group seeks to rejoin the major part of the ethnic group in another state”). “Out” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of STIR and DIRE MEN.

down.text: Gap outside old city, source of bloody riot
down.explanation: DISTURBANCE(i.e. “riot”). Solution is DISTANCE (i.e. “gap”) wrapped around or placed “outside” of UR (i.e. “old city” – a favourite of cryptic crossword setters) and B (i.e. “source of bloody”, i.e. the first letter of “bloody”), like so: DIST(UR-B)ANCE.

down.text: Go around in public, ultimately keen to stop criticism
down.explanation: OUTFLANK(i.e. “go around”). Solution is OUT (i.e. “in public”) followed by N (i.e. “ultimately keen”, i.e. the last letter of “keen”) once placed in or “stopping” FLAK (i.e. “criticism”), like so: OUT-FLA(N)K.

down.text: One in Somerset location left operating sporting event
down.explanation: BIATHLON(i.e. “sporting event”). Solution is I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) placed “in” BATH (i.e. “Somerset location”) and followed by L (a recognised abbreviation of “left”), then ON (i.e. “operating”), like so: B(I)ATH-L-ON.

down.text: Stop gambler somehow losing pounds, ending with nothing
down.explanation: EMBARGO(i.e. “stop”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “somehow”) of GAMBLER once the L has been removed (indicated by “losing pounds”, L being a recognised abbreviation of pounds weight, after the Latinlibra), followed by O (i.e. “nothing”), like so: EMBARG-O.

down.text: Short piece specially placed on ‘orse – it may ease swelling
down.explanation: ICE PACK(i.e. “it may ease swelling”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “specially placed”) of PIECE once the last letter has been removed (indicated by “short”). This is then followed by ‘ACK (i.e. “’orse”. A variant meaning of hack is a horse. The H is dropped from each), like so: ICEP-‘ACK.

down.text: Busiest afternoon accommodates it? Yes and no!
down.explanation: SIESTA. “Accommodates it” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, like so: BU(SIEST A)FTERNOON. The remainder of the clue plays on how siestas aren’t exactly busy occasions.

down.text: Mark part of body
down.explanation: COLON. Solution satisfies punctuation “mark” and “part of body”.

down.text: Among partners in game had to be bottom
down.explanation: NATES(i.e. “bottom” or the buttocks in anatomy). Solution is ATE (i.e. “had”) placed “among” N and S (i.e. “partners in game”, specifically a game of bridge. Partners are situated North and South, or East and West), like so: N(ATE)S.
